title: Canadian Syncope Risk Score
description: The Canadian Syncope Risk Score (CSRS) predicts 30-day serious adverse events in patients presenting with syncope to the emergency department. It helps identify low-risk patients who can be safely discharged and high-risk patients requiring further investigation or admission.

parameters.name: vasovagal_predisposition
parameters.description: Predisposition to vasovagal symptoms (triggered by being in a warm crowded place, prolonged standing, fear, emotion, or pain)

parameters.name: heart_disease_history
parameters.description: History of heart disease (CAD, atrial fibrillation or flutter, CHF, valvular disease)

parameters.name: systolic_bp_abnormal
parameters.description: Any systolic BP <90 or >180 mmHg in the emergency department

parameters.name: troponin_elevated
parameters.description: Troponin level above 99th percentile for normal population

result.name: csrs_score
result.description: Canadian Syncope Risk Score (-3 to 11 points)

ranges.interpretation: Very low risk of serious adverse event within 30 days. Consider discharge home with appropriate follow-up as needed. No specific syncope workup typically required.
Low risk of serious adverse event within 30 days. Consider discharge home with close follow-up. Outpatient evaluation may be appropriate based on clinical judgment.

Medium risk of serious adverse event within 30 days. Consider further ED evaluation and monitoring. Cardiac monitoring and additional testing may be warranted. Disposition based on findings and clinical judgment.
High risk of serious adverse event within 30 days. Recommend admission for cardiac monitoring and expedited evaluation for underlying causes. Consider cardiology consultation.

Very high risk of serious adverse event within 30 days. Strongly recommend admission to monitored setting. Urgent cardiology consultation and comprehensive evaluation for life-threatening causes of syncope.

references: Thiruganasambandamoorthy V, Kwong K, Wells GA, Sivilotti ML, Mukarram M, Rowe BH, et al. Development of the Canadian Syncope Risk Score to predict serious adverse events after emergency department assessment of syncope. CMAJ. 2016 Sep 6;188(12):E289-98. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.151469.

Thiruganasambandamoorthy V, Sivilotti MLA, Le Sage N, Yan JW, Huang P, Hegdekar M, et al. Multicenter Emergency Department Validation of the Canadian Syncope Risk Score. JAMA Intern Med. 2020 May 1;180(5):737-44. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2020.0288.

Thiruganasambandamoorthy V, Hess EP, Turko E, Perry JJ, Wells GA, Stiell IG. Outcomes in Canadian emergency department syncope patients--are we doing a good job? J Emerg Med. 2013 Feb;44(2):321-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jemermed.2012.06.028.
formula: Score = (-1 × vasovagal predisposition) + (1 × heart disease) + (2 × abnormal BP) + (2 × elevated troponin) + (1 × abnormal QRS axis) + (1 × prolonged QRS) + (2 × prolonged QTc) + (-2 × vasovagal diagnosis) + (2 × cardiac diagnosis)
notes: Use in patients ≥16 years presenting within 24 hours of syncope
Exclude: prolonged LOC >5 min, altered mental status, witnessed seizure, major trauma, intoxication
Serious adverse events: death, arrhythmia, MI, structural heart disease, aortic dissection, PE, severe hemorrhage, SAH
Vasovagal predisposition: warm crowded place, prolonged standing, fear, emotion, or pain
Heart disease: CAD, atrial fibrillation/flutter, CHF, valvular disease
